settings.descripton:
Rose Inc is clean beauty powered by science.

A partnership between Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and biotech company Amyris, it leverages sustainable innovation and nearly two decades of experience in the makeup chair. The result is indulgent color and skincare that outperforms in every category.

settings.description:
Model-turned-founder and Chief Creative Officer Rosie Huntington-Whiteley refines her professional experience as a model and editor into a sharp, smart aesthetic that anticipates and executes what the modern individual wants in terms of cosmetics, formula and performance.


Her experience working daily with beauty professionals in makeup, skin and hair makes her an insightful and creative collaborator who prioritizes innovative clean ingredients, sustainable solutions and high-performance, non-comedogenic formulations.

Amyris provides the proprietary science that puts Rose Inc at the forefront of clean beauty. As the world's leading manufacturer of sustainable ingredients made with synthetic biology and clean chemistry, it raises the bar for ethical â€” and efficacious â€” color and skincare.

settings.top_description: We take a dual approach to beauty, delivering instant results with lasting skincare benefits. Each formula challenges clean stereotypes with saturated color, visible luminosity and clinically proven results.
settings.title_text: "Time is a luxury, so these products create an instant effect with ease."
settings.descripton: With multiple benefits, our products free up space on shelves and in landfills. Their effortless application also frees up time in beauty routines.

settings.heading: SUSTAINABILITY AND RECYCLING DIRECTORY
settings.title_text: Light on packaging, heavy on sustainability
settings.description: No matter how beautiful a product looks on a vanity, it inevitably ends up in a landfill. At Rose Inc, sustainability outranks the superficial. Itâ€™s a conscious decision: prioritizing long-term environmental benefits over the short-term benefits of opulent packaging. All Rose Inc products are Leaping Bunny certified.

settings.top_description: Weâ€™re a clean brand, but our focus is on what goes into our formulas â€” not the 2,000 ingredients we leave out. We rely on clean active ingredients that deliver visible skincare benefits.
settings.title_text: "As someone who suffers from skin challenges, I know the importance of ingredients that deliver."
settings.descripton:
Â· 5 proprietary bioengineered botanical ingredients
Â· Skin-beneficial ingredients derived from plants
Â· Products clinically tested for visible results
Â· Safe synthetic ingredients that meet rigorous standards

settings.description: Sustainable packaging also includes FSC-certified paper cartons made with 30% hemp and rinse-off labels manufactured with a 90% PCR liner.
Rose Inc is Leaping Bunny certified. No animals are harmed in the making of Rose Inc products.

settings.top_description: While we value form as well as function, our commitment is to sustainability. Recycled and recyclable materials pair with thoughtful design to put environmental benefits before opulent packaging.

settings.title: CLEAN BEAUTY POWERED BY SCIENCE.
settings.description: Rose Inc leverages sustainable innovation and nearly two decades of experience in the makeup chair. The result is indulgent color and skincare that outperforms in every category.

settings.title: SQUALANE
settings.description: Pure, sustainable and 100% plant-derived moisture that adds weightless hydration.

settings.title: VITAMIN E
settings.description: Powerful antioxidant that nourishes and protects skin.

settings.title: SUGAR CANE
settings.description: Proprietary vegan squalane is derived from renewable sugar cane.

settings.title: SEA FENNEL EXTRACT
settings.description: Activates radiance, helping increase skin luminosity and smoothness.

settings.title: PINK CLAY POWDER
settings.description: Detoxifies skin.

settings.title: HYALURONIC ACID
settings.description: Helps smooth and plump to reduce fine lines and wrinkles.

settings.title: Key Ingredients
settings.description: Efficacy and ethics unite in formulas charged by proprietary bioengineered botanicals and safe synthetic ingredients.

settings.title: ACMELLA OLERACEA (PARACRESS) EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A skin-renewing active that brings an immediate smoothing effect to fine lines.
settings.source: Sourced from a species of flowering herb that originates in South America.
settings.benefit: This skin-renewing active has a smoothing effect on fine lines. It firms skin and visibly reduces the appearance of wrinkles.

settings.title: ACRYLATES/C10-30 ALKYL ACRYLATE CROSSPOLYMER
settings.short_description: Enhances the texture of skincare formulas to create a smooth, glossy appearance.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Acrylates enhance the texture of skincare and haircare formulas to create a smooth, glossy appearance.

settings.title: ALLANTOIN
settings.short_description: Helps moisturize, protect and promote healing.
settings.source: Found in many plants, including comfrey, horse chestnut and bearberry. Although it can be isolated from these plants, most allantoin in cosmetics and personal care products is made synthetically. Ours is synthetically derived.
settings.benefit: Allantoin helps lock in moisture, making it especially beneficial for dry or sensitive skin.

settings.title: ALUMINUM HYDROXIDE
settings.short_description: An opacifying agent used in color products.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: An opacifying agent used in color products. It also helps achieve higher color coverage with less pigment.

settings.title: ASCORBYL TETRAISOPALMITATE
settings.short_description: Provides antioxidant protection, increases collagen production and brightens the skinâ€™s appearance.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Known for myriad benefits, ascorbyl tetraisopalmitate penetrates into the deeper layers of the skin. It provides antioxidant protection from both UVB and UVA rays, increases collagen production and brightens skinâ€™s appearance by reducing melanogenesis.

settings.title: BENTONITE
settings.short_description: A multitasking ingredient that absorbs excess sebum from the skin and clears bad bacteria from pores.
settings.source: Derived from a colloidal clay that consists primarily of montmorillonite.
settings.benefit: Bentonite absorbs excess oil from the skin to make it appear smooth and matte. Its negative ionic charge means it attracts bad bacteria and toxins and clears them from the pores. Research has shown that bentonite can help to soothe skin conditions such as psoriasis and eczema.

settings.title: BENZYL ALCOHOL
settings.short_description: A gentle preservative.
settings.source: Naturally found in many fruits and teas and can also be produced synthetically.
settings.benefit: A gentle preservative.

settings.title: BLACK IRON OXIDE (CI 77499)
settings.short_description: Controls the depth of a foundation or mascara shade.
settings.source: Mineral.
settings.benefit: Black Iron Oxide controls the depth of a foundation or mascara shade.

settings.title: BLUE 1 LAKE (CI 42090)
settings.short_description: A common synthetic colorant that adds a brilliant blue hue.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: This common synthetic colorant is used in many beauty and food products. It adds a brilliant blue hue.

settings.title: C13-15 ALKANE
settings.short_description: A sustainable silicone alternative that helps blend formulas with a lightweight texture and glide.
settings.source: A proprietary Amyris ingredient sourced from sustainable and renewable sugar cane.
settings.benefit: This biodegradable emollient is also known as hemisqualane. It gives a fresh, gliding sensation and a powdery after feel to beauty formulas.

settings.title: C9-12 ALKANE
settings.short_description: A silicone alternative solvent used in formulating beauty products.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: C9-12 alkane is a solvent used in formulating beauty products.

settings.title: CANNABIS SATIVA SEED OIL
settings.short_description: A natural emollient that moisturizes and nourishes.
settings.source: Derived from the seeds of cannabis sativa plant.
settings.benefit: This natural emollient provides essential moisture and nourishment for the skin. It also helps strengthen the skin barrier.

settings.title: CAPRYLHYDROXAMIC ACID
settings.short_description: Preserves cosmetics by neutralizing metal ions and slowing the growth of mold.
settings.source: Derived from coconut.
settings.benefit: Caprylhydroxamic acid helps to preserve cosmetic products by neutralizing a formula's metal ions and slowing the growth of mold

settings.title: CAPRYLIC/CAPRIC TRIGLYCERIDE
settings.short_description: Provides a lightweight, non-greasy and gentle layer that is easily absorbed into the skin.
settings.source: Typically derived from coconut and other vegetable sources.
settings.benefit: An excellent emollient, caprylic or capric triglyceride provides a lightweight, non-greasy and gentle layer that's easily absorbed into the skin. Its mix of fatty acids replenish the skin's surface and resist moisture loss.

settings.title: CAPRYLYL GLYCOL
settings.short_description: A skin conditioning agent that adds moisture to skin for a softer feel.
settings.source: May be derived from palm or coconut oil or synthetically produced.
settings.benefit: A skin conditioning agent that adds moisture to the skin for a softer feel. It can also enhance preservatives in a formula.

settings.title: CELLULOSE GUM
settings.short_description: A plant-derived ingredient used as an emulsion stabilizer and thickener.
settings.source: Derived from the cell walls of green plants, such as wood pulp and cottonseeds.
settings.benefit: A plant-derived natural ingredient thatâ€™s used as an emulsion stabilizer and thickener.

settings.title: CERAMIDE NG
settings.short_description: A ceramide that keeps the skin barrier healthy and hydrated.
settings.source: Typically are derived from plants, such as wheat germ, or synthetically created.
settings.benefit: Ceramide NG keeps the skin barrier healthy and hydrated.

settings.title: CERAMIDE NP
settings.short_description: Maintains the skin barrierâ€™s function by reinforcing and replenishing its moisture.
settings.source: Created from a vegan bio-fermentation process, and typically derived from plants or synthetically created.
settings.benefit: Ceramides help to maintain the skin barrierâ€™s function by reinforcing and replenishing its moisture. They help prevent dehydration and improve the look and feel of dry skin.

settings.title: CETEARYL ALCOHOL
settings.short_description: A multitasking ingredient that gives skin a soft feel and adds body to creams and lotions.
settings.source: Primarily derived from coconut, palm, corn or vegetable oil.
settings.benefit: Cetearyl alcohol is a multitasking ingredient that gives skin a soft feel and adds body to creams and lotions. It also helps stabilize oil-water emulsions.

settings.title: CITRIC ACID
settings.short_description: A pH adjuster that can also function as an alpha hydroxy acid.
settings.source: Naturally found in citrus fruits, although when used in personal care products citric acid is primarily synthetic.
settings.benefit: Along with being a pH adjuster, citric acid can function as an AHA (alpha hydroxy acid) to stimulate healthy cell turnover by helping shed surface dead skin cells.

settings.title: CITRUS AURANTIUM AMARA FLOWER OIL
settings.short_description: An essential oil with a sweet scent.
settings.source: Derived from the bitter orange flower.
settings.benefit: This essential oil contains several fragrance components â€“ including linalool and limonene â€“ that give it a sweet scent.

settings.title: CITRUS AURANTIUM BERGAMIA FRUIT OIL
settings.short_description: A light citrus scent with floral hints commonly used in perfumes.
settings.source: Comes from the fruit rind of the bergamot orange.
settings.benefit: This essential oil has a light citrus scent featuring floral hints. It is commonly used as a top note in perfumes.

settings.title: COCO-CAPRYLATE/CAPRATE
settings.short_description: A lightweight emollient that absorbs quickly to leave a silky finish on skin.
settings.source: Mixture of esters of coconut alcohol with caprylic acid and capric acid.
settings.benefit: Coco-Caprylate/Caprate is an emollient that absorbs quickly to leave a dry but silky finish on skin.

settings.title: COPERNICIA CERIFERA (CARNAUBA) WAX
settings.short_description: A thickening agent that gives stability and body to formulas.
settings.source: Derived from the leaves of the Copernicia cerifera, a tropical palm tree found in Brazil.
settings.benefit: Used primarily as a thickening agent, copernicia cerifera wax also has film-forming and absorbent properties. It stabilizes and gives body to products, keeps stick formulas solid and gives a glossy shine.

settings.title: CRITHMUM MARITIMUM EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A natural tonic that activates radiance and helps increase skin luminosity and smoothness.
settings.source: An extract from the oil found in sea fennel or rock samphire.
settings.benefit: This multitasking natural tonic firms skin and reduces the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles. It improves skin barrier function, boosts cellular respiration and restores hydration.

settings.title: DISTEARDIMONIUM HECTORITE
settings.short_description: A multitasking ingredient that thickens formulas and enhances their water resistance.
settings.source: Derived organically from the hectorite clay.
settings.benefit: Along with its thickening function, disteardimonium hectorite prevents pigments from settling during storage in order to stabilize a product for longer. In addition, it enhances the water resistance of sunscreen formulas and gives a light, smooth feeling on skin.

settings.title: EUPHORBIA CERIFERA (CANDELILLA) WAX
settings.short_description: Easily absorbed into the skin to help prevent moisture loss.
settings.source: Derived from candelilla plants.
settings.benefit: Rich in nutrients, euphorbia cerifera wax is easily absorbed into the skin. It acts as a barrier to help prevent moisture loss.

settings.title: FARNESOL
settings.short_description: Gives a sweet, light and floral scent.
settings.source: Extracted from plants, including citronella, neroli, ylang-ylang, and tuberose; can also be created synthetically.
settings.benefit: Farnesol lends a light, sweet, floral scent thatâ€™s popular in fragrances.

settings.title: GERANIOL
settings.short_description: A common fragrance ingredient with a rose scent.
settings.source: Can be synthetic or sourced from rose oil, geranium, lemon and other essential oils.
settings.benefit: Geraniol is a common fragrance ingredient with a rose scent. It can be found in rose oil or in small quantities in geranium, lemon and many other essential oils.

settings.title: GLUCONOLACTONE
settings.short_description: Gently lifts dead skin cells to reveal smoother and more even skin beneath.
settings.source: Derived from gluconic acid, which is naturally produced by mammals in order to metabolize carbohydrates; can also be commercially produced from corn.
settings.benefit: Gluconolactone is a polyhydroxy acid that gently lifts dead skin cells to reveal smoother and more even skin beneath. It increases skin thickness and reduces the appearance of wrinkles without causing skin to become more sensitive to the sun.

settings.title: GLUCOSE
settings.short_description: Glucose is a natural sugar that helps bind moisture to skin and adds flavor to products.
settings.source: Derived from carbohydrates.
settings.benefit: A common monosaccharide, glucose is a natural sugar that helps bind moisture to skin. It is used in many lip products to add flavor.

settings.title: GLYCERIN
settings.short_description: A powerful humectant that attracts water to the skin, helping maintain its moisture level.
settings.source: A naturally occurring compound that can be obtained from natural sources like vegetable oil or cane sugar. It can also be manufactured synthetically.
settings.benefit: Glycerin, also known as glycerine or glycerol, is naturally present in skin. As a powerful humectant, it attracts water to the skin, helping maintain its moisture level. It also prevents products from drying out.

settings.title: GLYCERYL CAPRYLATE
settings.short_description: Restores skin's oils and helps regulate moisture.
settings.source: Derived from plants, fatty acids such as refined vegetable oil, or coconut or palm kernel oil.
settings.benefit: A co-emulsifier derived from various vegetable oils, glyceryl caprylate is a multifunctional ingredient that restores skin's oils and helps regulate moisture.

settings.title: GLYCOLIC ACID
settings.short_description: An alpha hydroxy acid that reveals newer, healthier skin.
settings.source: Sugar or made synthetically.
settings.benefit: A derivative of sugarcane, glycolic acid is an alpha hydroxy acid (AHA). AHAs loosen the glue-like substance that holds dull and dead skin cells on the topmost layer of skin, revealing newer, healthier skin. And because glycolic acid has the smallest molecular size of all AHAs, itâ€™s the most bio available and active, allowing it to penetrate skin the most easily. It is also a humectant, able to pull water into skin.

settings.title: HELIANTHUS ANNUUS (SUNFLOWER) SEED OIL
settings.short_description: A natural oil that supports the skin's barrier by keeping it hydrated.
settings.source: Expressed from sunflower seeds.
settings.benefit: Sunflower oil protects the surface of the skin, helping to keep it hydrated and smooth. Its soothing properties significantly speed up recovery of the skin barrier within an hour of use.

settings.title: HYALURONIC ACID
settings.short_description: A hydrophilic (water-loving) compound that aids in skin hydration.
settings.source: Composed of sugar carbohydrates derived from animal, plant or synthetic sources.
settings.benefit: Hyaluronic acid is a naturally occurring component of connective and skin tissue. Its hydrating properties help to moisturize and condition skin.

settings.title: HYDROGENATED CASTOR OIL
settings.short_description: Features unique moisturizing properties that stops moisture loss and keeps skin soft.
settings.source: Derived from castor beans.
settings.benefit: Derived from castor beans, hydrogenated castor oil boasts unique moisturizing properties. It stops moisture loss and keeps skin soft.

settings.title: HYDROGENATED VEGETABLE OIL
settings.short_description: A skin-renewing emollient that has a buttery feel for soft, supple skin.
settings.source: Made from edible oils extracted from olives, sunflowers and soybeans.
settings.benefit: A natural emollient, hydrogenated vegetable oil functions as a skin-conditioning or hair-conditioning agent.

settings.title: ILLITE
settings.short_description: A mineral-sourced thickener that enhances the texture of skincare formulas to create a smooth, silky finish.
settings.source: Derived from clay mineral.
settings.benefit: Sometimes referred to as â€œFrench green clay,â€ Illite is a mineral-sourced natural thickener. It is a good absorbent that helps calm irritated skin.

settings.title: ISOAMYL COCOATE
settings.short_description: An extremely light emollient that has a non-oily feel and absorbs quickly into skin.
settings.source: The ester of isoamyl alcohol (a natural solvent) and coconut fatty acid of 100% vegetable origin. It may be synthetic or derived from sugar beets, coconut oil or other plants.
settings.benefit: Isoamyl Cocoate is an extremely light liquid that has a non-oily feel and absorbs quickly into skin.

settings.title: ISOAMYL LAURATE
settings.short_description: A lightweight oily ester that provides a velvet-soft feeling.
settings.source: Comes from a variety of sources, but ours is derived from sugar and coconut.
settings.benefit: Isoamyl laurate is a lightweight oily ester that provides a velvet-soft feeling.

settings.title: ISOMALT
settings.short_description: A humectant that attracts water to the skin, helping maintain its moisture level.
settings.source: Derived from sugar beets.
settings.benefit: A sugar substitute derived from beets, isomalt helps preserve moisture in personal care products.

settings.title: ISONONYL ISONONANOATE
settings.short_description: An emollient ester that conditions skin and leaves a silky after feel.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Isononyl isononanoate is an emollient used to improve the texture and feel of a formulation. It makes skin supple with a smooth, non-greasy feel.

settings.title: ISOPENTYLDIOL
settings.short_description: An emollient that makes skin smooth with a dry, non-tacky finish.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Isopentyldiol is a water-soluble liquid that works with sorbitol for a longer-lasting moisturizing effect. Colorless and odorless, it gives skin a smooth, non-greasy feel.

settings.title: JOJOBA ESTERS
settings.short_description: Help retain hydration in skin and prevent moisture loss.
settings.source: Jojoba oil.
settings.benefit: Jojoba esters can function as a non-greasy emollient that helps retain hydration in skin and prevent moisture loss. Easily absorbed into the skin, they are also effective at improving the appearance of fine lines and increasing skin firmness.

settings.title: KAOLIN
settings.short_description: A clay that gives opacity to formulas and can also act as a non-drying absorbent.
settings.source: Naturally occurring in clay.
settings.benefit: Kaolin is a clay mineral whose fine, white powder is used to give opacity to cosmetic formulas. As a clay, it can gently absorb excess sebum with less drying, making it ideal for sensitive skin types.

settings.title: LACTIC ACID
settings.short_description: An alpha hydroxy acid often used to exfoliate and hydrate.
settings.source: Our lactic acid is synthetic, vegan and derived from fermented sugar. Lactic acid can also be derived from animal sources, including milk.
settings.benefit: Lactic acid is a water-soluble alpha hydroxy acid (AHA) derived from a variety of sources, most commonly sour milk or fermented sugar. Like all AHAs, lactic acid exfoliates and hydrates skin. It breaks down the material that holds onto dead skin cells, causing a gentle chemical exfoliation to reveal healthier-looking skin.

settings.title: LAUROYL LYSINE
settings.short_description: An amino acid derivative that gives a fresh, gliding sensation and a silky after feel.
settings.source: Made from the fatty acid found in coconut oil.
settings.benefit: An amino acid derivative, lauroyl lysine functions as a skin-softening and hair-conditioning agent. Its fatty acids also contribute to a productâ€™s texture, helping to bind together its solvents.

settings.title: LIMNANTHES ALBA SEED OIL
settings.short_description: An emollient plant oil rich in vitamin E and phytosterols.
settings.source: Derived from the seeds of the meadowfoam plant.
settings.benefit: Limnanthes alba seed oil is a non-greasy oil that is rapidly absorbed into the skin, much like jojoba oil. Ideal for products requiring a soft, silky feel, this natural ingredient can be used in skin and haircare products. It contains antioxidant components.

settings.title: LIMONENE
settings.short_description: A compound naturally found in citrus fruit and used as a fragrance.
settings.source: Citrus fruit.
settings.benefit: Limonene is a compound naturally found in citrus fruit and used as a fragrance in cosmetics and personal care products.

settings.title: LINALOOL
settings.short_description: A naturally derived oil used for its pleasant scent.
settings.source: Most frequently derived from lavender.
settings.benefit: Linalool is a naturally derived oil used for its pleasant scent. It's found in over 200 plants, including lavender, ylang-ylang, bergamot, jasmine and geranium.

settings.title: MALIC ACID
settings.short_description: A gentle alpha hydroxy acid that helps smooth skin.
settings.source: Derived from apples.
settings.benefit: Malic acid is an AHA. It can gently lift off the dead skin cells of the skin and make it more smooth and fresh.

settings.title: MANDELIC ACID
settings.short_description: A gentle alpha hydroxy acid that helps smooth and brighten skin.
settings.source: Derived from bitter almond.
settings.benefit: Mandelic acid is an alpha hydroxy acid (AHA) that gently exfoliates dead cells from the skinâ€™s surface in order to make it smoother.

settings.title: MENTHA PIPERITA (PEPPERMINT) LEAF EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A skin-conditioning agent that helps calm, purify and refresh.
settings.source: Extracted from peppermint leaves.
settings.benefit: Peppermint from the mint family can be found worldwide. It has astringent and antipruritic, antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties. It is the perfect ingredient for skincare products for acne.

settings.title: MICA
settings.short_description: A versatile mineral powder used to improve product performance and add light-reflecting properties.
settings.source: Mineral; Rose Inc's mica is sourced from suppliers who mine in the US or are a part of the Responsible Mica Initiative.
settings.benefit: Mica is a versatile and common mineral powder that comes in different particle sizes. It can be used to improve skin feel, increase product slip, give the product light-reflecting properties, enhance skin adhesion or serve as an anti-caking agent.

settings.title: MICROCRYSTALLINE CELLULOSE
settings.short_description: A plant-derived ingredient used as an emulsion stabilizer and thickener.
settings.source: A naturally occurring component derived from the cell walls of plants
settings.benefit: Microcrystalline cellulose is a gentle scrubbing agent that offers a natural alternative to synthetic ingredients. In addition to giving skin a soft, silky feel, this non-greasy powder can be used as a mattifying agent.

settings.title: MONTMORILLONITE
settings.short_description: A natural clay that absorbs sebum, purifies and hydrates skin.
settings.source: Natural clay found next to French village, Montmorillon.
settings.benefit: Montmorillonite is a multifunctional ingredient that optimizes the skinâ€™s natural processes by absorbing sebum and dirt, hydrating skin and reducing pore size.

settings.title: MORINGA OIL/HYDROGENATED MORINGA OIL ESTERS
settings.short_description: Maintains the skin barrierâ€™s function by reinforcing and replenishing its moisture.
settings.source: Derived from the seeds of the moringa oleifera, a small tree native to the Himalayan mountains.
settings.benefit: Moringa oil helps guard against moisture loss by enhancing skin barrier repair. It also replenishes skin with increased hydration.

settings.title: NIACINAMIDE
settings.short_description: Also known as vitamin B3, a water-soluble vitamin rich in benefits that improve skin's appearance.
settings.source: The ingredient used in skincare and cosmetics is created synthetically, however niacinamide is also found naturally in wheat, fish and some vegetables.
settings.benefit: Niacinamide is a water soluble vitamin known as Vitamin B3. Rich in benefits, it can help even out the look of skin tone, improve skin barrier function for greater hydration and improve the look of wrinkles.

settings.title: OCTYLDODECANOL
settings.short_description: A clear oil that adds moisture without a greasy after feel.
settings.source: Produced from natural, non-animal fats and oils.
settings.benefit: Octyldodecanol is a clear, odorless oil. In addition to adding moisture, it is excellent for pigment dispersion.

settings.title: PANTHENOL
settings.short_description: A provitamin of B5 with the ability to attract and hold moisture to skin.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: A provitamin of B5, panthenol has the ability to attract and hold moisture to skin and act as a lubricant.

settings.title: PENTAERYTHRITYL TETRAISOSTEARATE
settings.short_description: A liquid emollient that gives a rich, cushiony feel and high levels of gloss.
settings.source: Derived from isostearic acid.
settings.benefit: Pentaerythrityl tetraisostearate is a liquid emollient derived from isostearic acid. It functions as a thickener and binding agent, giving a rich, cushiony feel and high levels of gloss.

settings.title: PENTYLENE GLYCOL
settings.short_description: A synthetic chemical with antimicrobial properties that helps skin retain moisture.
settings.source: Often made synthetically. We use a bio-fermented source from sugarcane bygass.
settings.benefit: Pentylene glycol is a synthetic chemical with anti-microbial properties that helps skin retain moisture. It keeps both the product and skin from drying out.

settings.title: PISUM SATIVUM (PEA) SPROUT EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A plant extract that helps strengthen and revitalize hair from the root.
settings.source: Extracted from pea plants.
settings.benefit: Pisum sativum, or pea sprout extract, stimulates hair growth by revitalizing hair from the root. Packed with nutrients, this powerful ingredient can fully restore the vitality of denser hair in just three months.

settings.title: POGOSTEMON CABLIN LEAF OIL
settings.short_description: A light woody, earthy scent commonly used in perfumes.
settings.source: Most commonly derived from the leaves of the patchouli plant.
settings.benefit: An essential oil with a woody, earthy scent. It also helps prolong the aroma life.

settings.title: POLYGLYCERYL-3 POLYRICINOLEATE
settings.short_description: Absorbs quickly to leave a silky finish on skin.
settings.source: Derived from plants.
settings.benefit: Polyglyceryl-3 polyricinoleate is a plant-based ingredient used as a substitute for a synthetic emulsifier. Itâ€™s especially suited to lip balms and thick body butters.

settings.title: POLYHYDROXYSTEARIC ACID
settings.short_description: A soft wax that helps to add a creamy texture.
settings.source: Derived from castor oil.
settings.benefit: Polyhydroxystearic acid is a dispersing agent used in sunscreens and cosmetic products to distribute pigments evenly on to the skin.

settings.title: PROPANEDIOL
settings.short_description: A naturally derived ingredient that helps boost skin moisture.
settings.source: Synthetically and sustainably produced from corn sugar.
settings.benefit: Propanediol is a naturally derived ingredient used in cosmetics and personal care products as an emollient, humectant and solvent. It is a glycol that can help the absorption of ingredients and boost skin moisturization.

settings.title: PYRUS MALUS (APPLE) FRUIT EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A mild exfoliant that helps smooth, brighten and hydrate skin.
settings.source: Extracted from apples.
settings.benefit: Pyrus malus, or apple fruit extract, is loaded with proteins, sugars, vitamins and more. Its smoothing and moisturizing properties can be attributed to its mix of sugars, while acids provide a mild antibacterial exfoliant that brightens skin.

settings.title: RANUNCULUS FICARIA EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A plant extract that calms stressed skin.
settings.source: Extracted from the lesser celandine plant.
settings.benefit: Ranunculus ficaria extract protects stressed skin that has been damaged by environmental conditions. It is a calming ingredient that reduces visible redness in the skin.

settings.title: RED IRON OXIDE (CI 77491)
settings.short_description: A mineral pigment that gives a rust-red color to formulas.
settings.source: Mineral.
settings.benefit: This mineral pigment gives a rust-red color to products. Red iron oxide is also used to add pink tones to foundation.

settings.title: RICINUS COMMUNIS (CASTOR) SEED OIL
settings.short_description: Easily absorbed into the skin to help prevent moisture loss.
settings.source: Obtained from castor seeds.
settings.benefit: Castor seed oil is a mainstay of thick, gloss-giving formulas. This highly effective emollient also reduces skin moisture loss, making it a common addition to moisturizing products.

settings.title: ROSE EXTRACT
settings.short_description: Gives a sweet, light and floral scent.
settings.source: Extracted from rose petals.
settings.benefit: Rose extract is an intensely hydrating ingredient with a complex concentration of antioxidants, minerals and vitamins. It helps minimize redness and soothe irritation, making it an ideal match for dry, mature or sensitive skin.

settings.title: ROSMARINUS OFFICINALIS (ROSEMARY) LEAF EXTRACT
settings.short_description: An antioxidant-rich extract that helps calm skin.
settings.source: Extracted from the rosemary plant.
settings.benefit: Rosemary leaf extract benefits the skin with antioxidant components and a calming effect that can be useful in mitigating several common skin issues.

settings.title: SACCHARIDE ISOMERATE
settings.short_description: A plant-derived ingredient that provides deep, long-lasting moisture.
settings.source: Derived from plants or algae through a bio-fermentation process.
settings.benefit: Saccharide isomerate is a plant-derived moisturizer that mimics the natural carbohydrate fraction found in the upper layer of the skin. Its ability to bind to the skin with more strength than other moisturizing ingredients keeps skin hydrated longer than usual.

settings.title: SALIX ALBA (WILLOW) BARK EXTRACT
settings.short_description: A natural, salicylate-rich extract that helps purify skin.
settings.source: Extracted from the bark of the white willow tree.
settings.benefit: Salix alba is a natural extract that has been used for thousands of years. It is famous for its anti-inflammatory, astringent and antiseptic properties.

settings.title: SILICA
settings.short_description: An absorbent that wicks away excess moisture and oil from the skin's surface.
settings.source: Synthetically made or found in sandstone, clay or granite.
settings.benefit: Silica can be used in skincare or cosmetics in many ways, such as an abrasive in scrubs, an absorbent powder, anti-caking agent, bulking agent, opacifying agent and suspending agent. It is most commonly used as an absorbent because of its ability to absorb excess moisture and oil from the surface of skin. Amorphous silica is the form used in personal care products, which does not have the same health risks as crystalline silica.

settings.title: SODIUM BENZOATE
settings.short_description: A preservative that prevents bacteria growth in skincare formulations.
settings.source: Derived from the sodium salt of benzoic acid, which occurs naturally in many fruit, vegetables, seafood and diary products.
settings.benefit: Sodium benzoate functions as a preservative and prevents bacteria growth in skincare formulations.

settings.title: SODIUM CITRATE
settings.short_description: A salt that helps adjust pH to be skin compatible.
settings.source: The sodium salt of citric acid, which naturally occurs in citrus fruits, corn and other foods.
settings.benefit: Sodium citrate is a salt used to adjust the pH of a product. It helps extends the lifespan of a product by neutralizing the metal ions in its formula.

settings.title: SODIUM HYDROXIDE
settings.short_description: A very alkaline ingredient that helps adjust pH to be skin compatible.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Sodium hydroxide is a very alkaline ingredient that helps to adjust pH.

settings.title: SODIUM LACTATE
settings.short_description: A natural ingredient that adds moisture to the skin.
settings.source: Produced by the fermentation of sugar from corn or beets.
settings.benefit: Sodium lactate is the sodium salt found in lactic acid. A natural ingredient approved by both ECOCERT and COSMO, it adds moisture to the skin and helps to regulate the pH value of a formula.

settings.title: SODIUM LAUROYL GLUTAMATE
settings.short_description: A mild surfactant with foaming properties.
settings.source: Derived from natural sources such as coconut oil, palm kernel oil, and fermented sugar.
settings.benefit: Derived from natural sources, sodium lauroyl glutamate is a mild, amino acid-based surfactant with foaming properties. It's gentle enough for sensitive and baby skin.

settings.title: SODIUM PCA
settings.short_description: A natural moisturizer that helps skin retain water to remain well hydrated.
settings.source: Derived from oils, plants and fruits.
settings.benefit: The sodium salt form of PCA is an important skin-identical ingredient and great natural moisturizer that helps the skin to hold onto water and stay nicely hydrated.

settings.title: SODIUM PHYTATE
settings.short_description: An ingredient that keeps a product uniform over time.
settings.source: Made synthetically.
settings.benefit: Sodium phytate keeps a product uniform over time, so there are no color or texture changes.

settings.title: SQUALANE
settings.short_description: A mega-moisturizing molecule that beautifully mimics our skinâ€™s natural hydration.
settings.source: Derived from various plant sources. Our squalane is sourced from sustainable and renewable sugarcane.
settings.benefit: Squalane is the shelf-stable version of squalene, the natural skin hydrator our sebaceous glands make. Squalene keeps our skinâ€™s outer layer moisturized and protected, but as we get older, we make less and less. Thatâ€™s where squalane comes in: this mega-moisturizing molecule beautifully mimics our skinâ€™s natural hydration.

settings.title: TOCOPHEROL
settings.short_description: Also known as vitamin E, a chemical compound that protects skin from free radical damage and strengthens the skin barrier.
settings.source: Can be synthetic or sourced from vegetable oils, nuts or seeds.
settings.benefit: Tocopherols are a class of naturally occurring chemical compounds referred to as vitamin E. They're used in skincare products for their ability to protect skin from free radical damage and strengthen the skin barrier.

settings.title: WATER/AQUA/EAU
settings.short_description: Used primarily as a solvent to dissolve other ingredients.
settings.source: Several types of purified water can be used, including distilled, deionized and demineralized water.
settings.benefit: In cosmetics and personal care products, water is used primarily as a solvent to dissolve other ingredients. Water is also used with various oils to form emulsions.

settings.title: XANTHAN GUM
settings.short_description: A binder that keeps product texture from becoming too thin or runny.
settings.source:
Produced through biotech or derived from various sugar sources or egg.
We use a fermented vegan source.
settings.benefit: In skincare and cosmetic products, xanthan gum acts a binder to keep product texture from becoming too thin or runny. It's a natural ingredient often found in emulsions, helping to bind together oil-and-water formulas.

settings.title: YELLOW IRON OXIDE (CI 77492)
settings.short_description: Provides a yellow tint to cosmetic products.
settings.source: Mineral.
settings.benefit: Yellow Iron Oxide provides a yellow tint.

settings.title: ZINGIBER OFFICINALE (GINGER) ROOT EXTRACT
settings.short_description: Calms skin and reduces the look of redness.
settings.source: Ginger root.
settings.benefit: Ginger root extract helps calm skin and reduce the look of redness.

settings.title: All Ingredients
settings.description: Our strict guidelines minimize the impact across our supply chain, packaging and formulas, which undergo rigorous testing and demonstrate clinical results.

settings.left_dropcap_description_1: The beauty space has become extremely crowded in the past few years. What advice would you give to better navigate shopping for great products?
settings.left_dropcap_description_2: I think it's an exciting time. There's a lot of stuff to sort through and hopefully that's where beauty editors help guide you through. But I also think you should feel very empowered as the consumer, because brands are crawling over themselves trying to get your attention, so you hold a lot of power. Talk with your dollar, because brands are paying attention to what people are talking about and are interested in. Beauty trends start with the consumer, not the other way around.
settings.left_dropcap_description_3: What do you think we learned about beauty from the global pandemic?
settings.left_dropcap_description_4: I think thereâ€™s a tendency for some people not familiar with the beauty industry to think of beauty in general as something superficial. I think naysayers, hopefully, will see with the last year of the pandemic, that people have found solace in some of these beauty rituals.

settings.text_center: Though you are completely entitled to reject the beauty industry as a whole, I would hope that [people recognize that beauty] can be a respite and escape. Whether youâ€™re taking a long, leisurely shower or painting your nails, you're taking that time to really indulge in that aspect of your routine and it brings some sense of peace and calm or helps you feel more beautiful or you feel like you have your life together, even when everything else around you is a flaming dumpster. Itâ€™s a means of self-care that goes beyond just the practicality of grooming yourself and it is a way to show yourself some self-love.

settings.dropcap_description_1: Who were your first beauty icons?
settings.dropcap_description_2:
This is where a lot of women would consider their mom as their first beauty icon, but my mom was so not a beauty girl. I didn't see my mom wear makeup until I was maybe 14, when she put on mascara to go to a wedding and I was like â€˜what are you wearing?â€™ She was about skincare and had a very healthy relationship with the way she looked, which I think set my expectations for what a grown-ass woman should prioritize.

The only person who I thought was very interesting in what she did with her hair and makeup was Lizzie McGuire, because she crimped it and wore crazy accessories and classic, early-â€™90s frosted eyeshadow...Now, Tracee Ellis Ross is my ultimate beauty icon because she radiates such infectious positivity. Sheâ€™s the only celebrity Iâ€™ve asked to take a selfie with...

settings.quotes: Not having to answer to anyone when it comes to your makeup is really, really important.

settings.dropcap_description_1: What do you try to communicate with your personal beauty look?
settings.dropcap_description_2: I personally have never chosen to wear a complexion product like foundationâ€¦ There are points when I'll slap on some concealer if I'm going to a meeting, but I don't feel the need to cover up. Iâ€™m not saying this needs to be the case for everyoneâ€¦ For me, I work so hard with skincare that I feel like, take it or leave it, this is what [my complexion] looks like.
settings.dropcap_description_3: Whatâ€™s your dream beauty product that has yet to be invented?
settings.dropcap_description_4: A brow pomade or gel that can add color and definition but can also actually regrow your brows without the risks that come with some serums on the market.

settings.dropcap_description_1: What beauty treatment would you regularly book and pay for if you weren't getting a freebie or industry discount?
settings.dropcap_description_2: Nothing beats the instant gratification of getting a really good facial with an exceptional facial massage. When you find someone that can beat your face senseless and you leave with your cheekbones having lifted two inches? Yes. I think facials in general should be a maintenance thing you have to do. If you deep clean your apartment every once in a while, you should deep clean your face every once in a while, too. I paid for facials before I was an editor and I will continue to pay for facials for as long as I can afford it.
settings.dropcap_description_3: Lymphatic drainage, Gua Sha, all of thatâ€”I absolutely believe in it.
settings.dropcap_description_4: I see Taylor Worden and Sofie Pavitt most frequently. They always have the coolest gadgets to help bring dull, lackluster skin back to life, and truly live and breathe skincare for their clients. I trust them implicitly. There's also a woman named Nina at Dr. Adam Kolker's office who will give you the best facial massage of your life. And definitely Aida Bicaj if she's available. She's such a veteran in the aesthetics space and will leave you with the most insane glow.
settings.dropcap_description_5: What's the best beauty advice you've ever received?
settings.dropcap_description_6: Have fun playing with different aspects of what the beauty industry offers, but recognize beauty is fleeting and at the end of the day you have to be comfortable with who you are as a person, not what your outer shell looks like. A big reason why I made the shift from fashion to beauty is because it's a little more accessible and it's constantly changing. It's excitingâ€¦ I really believe beauty should be an experience that doesn't make you feel like you have to change parts of yourself. It should really be a celebration of who you are and a point of self expression. There's no right or wrong way to interact with â€˜beautyâ€™.

settings.dropcap_description_1: What do you think is the most underrated beauty practice?
settings.dropcap_description_2: I think a lot of people underestimate sleep, especially in New York. The hustle culture tells us that we should be getting up at 6:00 a.m. and going on a run and doing all this shit before the sun rises or whatever. I love sleep more than anything and Iâ€™m telling you, you will feel and look like shit if you do not sleep enough, so build it into your schedule.
settings.dropcap_description_3: What product is always worth the splurge?
settings.dropcap_description_4:
Finding a sunscreen that you really like and looks good under the makeup that you choose to wear. If it's expensive, it's worth the investment to pay more for really good sunscreen that's comfortable, doesn't cause breakouts, and blends into your skin well. Itâ€™s worth trying out a couple of formulas to find the one that really, really works for you.

The Tatcha Silken Pore Perfecting Sunscreen is my longtime stalwart for its silky finish and added octisalate, which helps keep the formula from breaking down (which means longer sun protection). I like using Self Reflect Probiotic Moisturizing Sunscreen Zinc Oxide SPF 32 in the winter for an added boost of hydration and the Saie Sunvisor SPF is great if you want extra skin-care benefits and a physical formula without a speck of white cast. My favorite chemical formula is Solid & Striped Face Sunscreen. It's more of a buttery serum texture that sinks right into the skin so you'd never even know that you're wearing a sunscr

settings.dropcap_description_1: Whatâ€™s a beauty product or practice thought would never work but actually does?
settings.dropcap_description_2:
I just tried this last night. Have you heard of the Bare Hands Dry Gloss Manicure Kit?

It's a kit that comes with a cuticle oil and a glass file with a proprietary blend of minerals on it. You use it to shine the top of your nail bed and it becomes so shiny, it looks like you're wearing a clear top coat. It's the most insane thing...I'm like, â€˜what is this witchcraft?â€™

settings.heading: 1. Calm & Depressurize Irritated Eyes
settings.description:
On clean skin, apply a cooling eye mask, like Knesko Black Pearl Detox Collagen Eye Mask. â€œThe charcoal can pull out impurities and cut itchiness,â€ MarÃ­ says. As the eye mask calms swollen or itchy skin under the eyes, MarÃ­ suggests using her self-massage technique to further reduce bloat and begin to drain the lymph: Anchor index fingers near the center of the forehead at the hairline, then use thumbs to apply light pressure while tracing the arch of the brow, above bone, starting at the inner corners and ending at the temples. Repeat a few times.
The esthetician says this protocol can take an indulgent 10 minutes or more to completeâ€”or whatever time you can spare. â€œJust a few movements around the eye area will really help to push that lymph through for increased circulation and decreased puffiness,â€ she says, adding the process may also help ease sinus pressure and calm irritation.

settings.text_center:
When asked for tips and tricks from the professional makeup chair, actress Courtney Halverson first sets the stage. â€œIâ€™ve worked on a lot of horror films and thrillers, so oftentimes the makeup my charactersâ€™ wear is either minimal...or else a bit gory,â€ she explains. â€œSo I may not be the best person to ask!â€ Still, her professional range â€” sheâ€™s also a blogger with a cinema-inspired eye â€” provides a wealth of beauty knowledge. â€œOn the rare occasion I get to play a character who looks their best, I always ask a lot of questions in the makeup chair,â€ she says. Spoiler alert: She shares her tricks for faking fresh makeup and creating a natural flush ahead.

Born and raised in Orange County, California, Halverson has been acting since childhood â€” you may have seen her in True Detective, Criminal Minds, or Unfriended â€” and blogging for a decade. â€œMy first job-job was working at a secondhand shop,â€ she says. â€œI was a buyer of vintage and new clothing for a while, and then opened my own Etsy shop of vintage reselling, and thatâ€™s why I started taking photos of myself.â€ This led to blogging which led to her love of all things beauty and now she balances it all from Los Angeles.

settings.dropcap_description_1: As an actress, what kind of makeup tips and tricks have you learned on set?
settings.dropcap_description_2: I had a makeup artist on a TV show once tell me that she almost never puts makeup on noses, or else a very thinned version, as that tends to make our faces look overly made up and like a plastic doll. Iâ€™ve stuck with this and try not to make my whole face one tone â€” and typically skip foundation or concealer on my nose. I also always admire how many products I see makeup artists mix together, and try to do that a bit myself as the colors and tones always seem more lively when theyâ€™re not one note. For instance I mix my Saie Slip Tint with equal parts sunscreen for a more even, toned look that still reads as skin. I do the same with lip colors and always blend two together. It makes me feel like an artist and itâ€™s fun to see the combinations that work best.
settings.dropcap_description_3: What beauty rituals did you create for yourself in the pandemic?
settings.dropcap_description_4:
I think the biggest change for me was skipping out on makeup most days. I used to attend a decent amount of events and in-person auditions, so I reached for makeup frequently. Once I was at home and not really seeing others as much, I began to focus more on skincare and taking my time with that rather than covering my skin with makeup. Oils have always been key for me, I really donâ€™t use many creams, so I started focusing on taking time to apply face oils and use that as an opportunity for a facial massage, both in the evening and in the morning. Iâ€™m finding even now that I donâ€™t use makeup in the same way; itâ€™s something that is fun and I like for enhancement, but it doesnâ€™t feel as needed now that my skin is happier.

Bi-weekly masking also became an easy thing for me to do while answering emails and editing photos, as well as taking a long bath and really moisturizing my body afterwards. I used to just towel off after a shower and move on with my day, but now I really spend time bringing the moisture back to my skin after stepping out of the bath.

settings.left_dropcap_description_1: What do you believe about beauty now that you didnâ€™t before?
settings.left_dropcap_description_2: I used to think of beauty and skincare routines as being something I had to do, like a chore. I didnâ€™t believe that my beauty routine could be more than that, but now itâ€™s become this slow moment and a chance for me to check in with myself. Not with my physical appearance, but with how I am feeling, in real time. I put my phone away and just take the time to really get lost in the moment.
settings.left_dropcap_description_3: What is your first beauty memory?
settings.left_dropcap_description_4: I remember my great-grandmother had this really beautiful face powder, with a little puff inside, and I would watch her put it on after a meal when we were out. I was fascinated by the glamour of it. It had a scent to it, and came in a beautiful floral-printed circular box. She had been using the same powder her whole life, and my mom and I would have to send it to her in the Midwest from California because they stopped carrying it at her local shop. I actually just spotted it recently online and the formula hasnâ€™t changed since 1935.

settings.quotes: "It wasnâ€™t until I was older that I began to embrace all of the things I used to hateâ€¦"

settings.dropcap_description_1: Where do you find your creative inspiration?
settings.dropcap_description_2: Iâ€™m a huge fan of magazine editorials and love turning to print for inspiration. Thereâ€™s nothing quite like picking up a few magazines to thumb through; itâ€™s just a nice, quiet ritual for me. I also really love period pieces, and watch a lot of costume dramas in general. There is a touch of that in my content, as I always want my work to feel a bit â€˜out of timeâ€™, where itâ€™s a bit hard to place exactly when, and where, a photo was shot. A bit of romance, maybe a bit of drama, and always a touch of cinema is what I aim for in my work.
settings.dropcap_description_3: What attracted you to makeup originally? Has that changed over time?
settings.dropcap_description_4: I was first attracted to makeup when I was a very young teen because I saw it as a way to change how I look. Everything that I sought out was in an effort to hide the things that I felt made me ugly. I gravitated towards thick concealer to hide my freckles, and chose the wrong shade of foundation because I hated being pale and so desperately wanted to be this idea of a California girl; a beautiful blonde with a bronze glow. I used self-tanner exactly once in my life  because I remember hearing someone in grade school say that I had â€˜librarian legsâ€™, whatever that means, and I stained my skin orange. It wasnâ€™t until I was older that I began to embrace all of the things I used to hate [like] my freckles, my pale skin, my red hair, and to not use makeup as a way to change any of that.

settings.dropcap_description_1: What are your top five beauty essentials?
settings.dropcap_description_2: Mara Universal Oil, Furtuna Skin Eye Cream, Saie Beauty Slip Tint, Costa Brazil Body Oil, Summer Fridays R+R Mask
settings.dropcap_description_3: What are some of your go-to tricks for makeup application?
settings.dropcap_description_4: I like a damp beauty sponge. I use Caudalie Beauty Elixir on my sponge for a really spa-like experience. I also like to thin my makeup out a bit, and mix a bit of Saie Sunscreen into whatever foundation Iâ€™m using to allow my skin to show through and to add to my SPF. For blush, I like to put a small amount on the tip of my nose to give a natural flush.
settings.dropcap_description_5: What is your skincare regimen like?
settings.dropcap_description_6:
I have pretty sensitive skin, so I keep my products minimal. In the morning I start by pressing face oil into my skin; I like Mara Universal Oil or their Vitamin C Oil. I use a gua sha tool to help reduce any puffiness and to sort of sculpt my face a bit. I pat Furtuna Skin Eye Cream in and finish with Saie Sunscreen. Iâ€™ll maybe do a mask if I have a shoot coming up, but I usually just let my skin be on most days.

I wash my face in the evening with Mara Cleansing Oil if I wasnâ€™t wearing makeup. If I was wearing makeup, I use Augustinus Bader Cleansing Balm followed by the Cleansing Oil. I use muslin cloths to dry my skin and pat in Mara Retinol Oil. I apply Caudalie Resveratrol Eye Cream, and then use Biologique Recherche p50 on my chest where I have some fine lines forming from the way I sleep. I follow that with Furtuna Skin Oil, which I pat in from my neck all the way down my dÃ©colletage.

settings.quotes: "I like to put a small amount [of blush] on the tip of my nose to give a natural flush."

settings.dropcap_description_1: How do you take care of your hair?
settings.dropcap_description_2: Iâ€™m pretty no-frills when it comes to my hair care, and try to wash my hair as infrequently as possible. My natural red hair has turned brown over the years, so I do dye it, and washing it makes the red fade very fast. I rely on a weekly color mask from Christophe Robin to help redeposit the color and I use dry shampoo a lot. My favorite is this brush-on version from Crown Affair. I try to limit aerosols and it just feels so chic to apply it right around my hairline and where I need it.
settings.dropcap_description_4: I like to keep my hair short and curled under at the ends. I use a paddle brush and my hair dryer when itâ€™s wet to achieve this, and then really just let it do itâ€™s own thing for a few days after. I donâ€™t brush my hair daily, but do use a wide tooth comb from Crown Affair to keep it presentable. I am so happy that claw clips are back in style because they are perfect for warm summer nights.

settings.dropcap_description_1: When do you feel most confident in your beauty?
settings.dropcap_description_2: I feel most confident when I stick with the basics. Simple, glowy skin and maybe a splash of color and combed brows is what feels most me. I love to play with a bold lip, but truthfully, I feel most myself with a more minimal look. I like the idea that someone can see exactly who I am and that my skin can shine through. And of course a really lovely perfume goes miles and makes me feel especially confident. Scent is so important.
settings.dropcap_description_3: What would someone never guess about you?
settings.dropcap_description_4: I have always joked that my third wave career will be me starting an artisanal homemade butter company. It started out as a joke, but the older I get the more I like the idea.

settings.text_center:
To our community,

Today marks the start of an exciting new chapter. As you know, beauty has played a role in my life for as long as I can remember. For almost 20 years, Iâ€™ve had the privilege of watching some of the industryâ€™s most iconic beauty experts and learning from their work. But, like you, I had an endless list of questions.

If youâ€™ve been following the Rose Inc editorial site over the last three years, then you know about my ongoing quest for information when it comes to the best ingredients, formulas and packaging available. And Iâ€™m thrilled to show the result: a beauty experience you can touch, swatch, wear and â€” most importantly â€” feel good about. Meet the new Rose Inc and the Modern Essentials collection, a selection of formulas that have become essential to my beauty routine.

Weâ€™re proud to deliver effective and effortless formulas, proprietary ingredients that are clinically proven, best-in-class sustainability practices, and an indulgent experience. This is a new start, but the journey has just begun.

Weâ€™ll continue exploring together, as a community, and discover ways to make the beauty industry a better, more sustainable place. Welcome to the new Rose Inc.

Warmly,
RHW
Press play to see how RHW creates an instantly refined evening look using the brand new Modern Essentials Collection, then shop the products and follow along on Instagram for the latest on Rose Inc.
Photographed by Adrian Martin.

With more than a quarter million followers on Instagram, editorial and DIY nail art aficionado Amy Le has become something of an anomaly. Pre-pandemic, her following was a modest 30,000 â€” nothing to scoff at, but certainly not the accredited fame she has garnered over the last year and a half. Le got her start working in neighborhood nail salons and gained notoriety in the L.A. nail world thanks to the looks she created on herself for Instagram â€”plus reposts from clients like Amelie Zilber, Nastia Liukin, and Brittany Xavier. Now, she's one of the most in-demand nail artists in the city, working with brands and publications like Revolve and Allure. Today Le is sharing three inspiring looks to bring to your local salon, her favorite simple nail art recommendations to DIY, and her top nail care tips and products with Rose Inc.

Salon Inspiration

Not for the DIY novice, these are the looks best suited for a salon visit with your favorite local artist.

settings.heading: Amyâ€™s "Happy Mani"
settings.description: Even if you only use one color on each hand, having different designs on each nail keeps it interesting and shows off a bit of your personality, Le says.

settings.heading: OmbrÃ© Nails
settings.description: A classic look that never goes out of style. Amy notes that vertical ombrÃ© nails are much easier to achieve than the horizontal ones, and are a welcome variation to the traditional version

settings.heading: The Grid Mani
settings.description: "These are simple and chic, but you may need a professional to get those crisp lines," Amy says. Adorn them with gold leaf, gemstones, or decals to add a little spice, or you can even fill in some of the squares for a checkerboard look.

settings.quotes: â€œYou really can't mess this up.â€

settings.text_center:
DIY Inspiration

Le selected these simple designs for those with a few products, some basic tools, and the desire to craft something beautiful at home.

settings.heading: Negative Space
settings.description: No tools, no problem. "No nail art brushes necessary!" Le says. These negative-space swoops are truly foolproof because you can shape them however you want, just start with your lighter color to ensure each coat of color dries so the second color goes on smoothly.

settings.heading: Abstract Art
settings.description: Those with a pack of brushes can level up with this look. "Pick as many colors as you want and fill in random sections on your nails,â€ she says. "You really can't mess this up.â€

settings.quotes: â€œI wake up with baby hands every time!â€

settings.text_center:
Amyâ€™s Tips To Extend Your Manicure

Once you've made a trip to the salon â€” or tried your hand at recreating Leâ€™s trend picks at home â€” you're going to want to do your best to care for your nails and hands to prolong the life of your manicure. Here are Le's top tips for strong, healthy nails.

1. "Healthy nails start from within," says Amy, recommending that those who are able to add a biotin supplement to their wellness routine, should.

2. Cuticle oil and hand cream are an absolute must. "Especially right now, with all the excessive hand sanitizer and hand washing, your nails and hands are getting dried out due to the high alcohol levels," she says. "If your hands aren't properly moisturized, you will notice your nails are more prone to chipping and breaking, and hangnails will occur more often."

Her favorite scented cuticle oil is Essie Apricot Cuticle Oil and her favorite unscented cuticle oil is CND Solar Oil, which contains jojoba oil and mimics the oils found on your skin, so it absorbs quickly. She's partial to the Summer Fridays Jet Lag Mask for her hand cream. "I cannot sleep without it," Amy raves. "It's the last step of my night routine â€” I massage it all over my face and use the excess for my hands before bed. I wake up with baby hands every time!"

3. The less your nails are in water, the better. "I'm sure you notice that soft and bendy feel after you finish a sink full of dishes or after a long bubble bath,â€ Le says. â€œYour nail bed is like a sponge. [Theyâ€™re] porous and absorb water, which weakens your nails.â€ She recommends opting for gloves when cleaning or doing the dishes and avoid soaking your nails at the salon, which will help to keep your paint job fresher, longer.

Photographed by Amy Le.

In the world of skincare, â€œitâ€ ingredients seem to come and go. This oversaturated reality causes many of us to feel overwhelmed when it comes to figuring out what products to try. But if thereâ€™s a staple you should include in your routine, itâ€™s likely hyaluronic acid.

â€œItâ€™s an important hydrating compound made up of sugars and is both naturally-occurring and found in the human body,â€ says board-certified dermatologist Caroline Robinson MD, FAAD. â€œIt powerfully attracts moisture throughout the deeper layers of the skin and in other areas of the body such as our joints.â€

In addition to it being a powerful hydrator, itâ€™s also important to note that hyaluronic acid comes in many different â€œmolecular weights,â€ each having different functions, says Jessica Kizovski, the product development manager at Rose Inc. â€œLarger forms of HA help to hydrate the top layers of the skin,â€ she says, adding that larger molecules create a protective barrier across the skin. â€œSmaller forms are able to penetrate slightly deeper and hydrate the skin from within,â€ she adds. â€œIn general, the larger the molecule, the harder it is to penetrate the skin.â€ That means not all HA is created equal.

To help you figure out which hyaluronic acid is right for you, top experts weigh in on what the ultra-hydrating ingredient is, why itâ€™s important to use, and when it is most recommended to use it, ahead.

settings.description:
What is hyaluronic acid?

â€œHA is considered a humectant, which is a hydrating molecule that attracts water to the skin,â€ says Samantha Mims, aesthetician and founder of Dermasaa. Dr. Robinson adds that, â€œIn our skin, it powerfully attracts moisture throughout the deeper layers and in other areas of the body.â€ This includes joints, where it acts to lubricate and cushion the body. â€œIn dermatology, we also use injectable hyaluronic acid gels as an injectable filler to hydrate or re-volumize areas of loss.â€

What are the benefits of HA??

Given that itâ€™s so hydrating, hyaluronic acid is most beneficial to use for those with drier skin types. â€œIt moisturizes and attracts more moisture to the skin at the same time,â€ Dr. Robinson says, nothing that itâ€™s also safe for all skin types. Mims recommends HA for mature skin, too. â€œItâ€™ll build skin collagen and reduce the signs of premature aging,â€ she says. For example, those who experience fine lines, â€œHyaluronic acid can help to hydrate them, making lines look less apparent,â€ Dr. Robinson says.

When is the best time to use HA?

With the popularization of multistep-routines, determining what order to use which product and ingredient can feel intimidating. Mims suggests thinking of HA as a pre-moisturizer. In terms of timing and frequency, Mims says this: I believe in moderate use. Every other day or just a few times out of the week is enough.â€

Dr. Robinson also agrees that too much of a good thing can sometimes have negative effects on the skin. â€œMany products, including moisturizers, now incorporate hyaluronic acid into their formulas,â€ she says. â€œThis means that sometimes we are doubling and tripling up on this active ingredient in our skin care routines.â€. In other words, always check the ingredients on all of the products in your routine. â€œUsing too much hyaluronic acid can have the opposite of the intended effect on the skin and actually dry the skin out,â€ the docto adds.I recommend sticking to once or twice daily use in no more than one step in your routine, morning and night.â€

settings.quotes: â€œHA is considered a humectant, which is a hydrating molecule that attracts water to the skinâ€

settings.description:
What are the different types of HA?

A common form is hydrolyzed hyaluronic acid. â€œThis form of hyaluronic acid undergoes a slight chemical modification where the molecule is essentially â€˜cut upâ€™ into smaller pieces,â€ says Rose Incâ€™s KizovskiThis modification allows for the new, smaller versions to penetrate the skin deeper than virgin HA, while still focusing on surface level hydration.â€.

Sodium hyaluronate, the sodium salt of hyaluronic acid, is another form. â€œThis version is known to penetrate the furthest into the skin due to its small size,â€ Kizovski adds.â€œThis form of HA is small enough to penetrate through your pores and is known for prolonged stability within cosmetic formulations, making it extremely popular within the skincare world.â€.

It is also important to note that HA can have different origins: from animal sources or, even created synthetically through bacterial fermentation.

How to apply HA

â€œThe skin always better absorbs HA when it's applied directly onto damp skin,â€ Mims shares, reminding us that all products actually penetrate best when the skin is damp. â€œThe best way to use HA is while the skin is clean and before your moisturizer.â€ Dr. Robinson adds. â€œ[Applying it to damp skin]can help pull the moisture from the water on your skin into the skin as opposed to the other way around.â€

settings.quotes: Shop our favorite hydrating skincare and makeup

settings.text_center:
Some beauty professionals make a living following trends, while others make a career by setting them. Kristie Streicher, esteemed brow artist and co-owner of Striiike Salon in Beverly Hills, falls into the latter category thanks to her eternally-chic take on a full, bushy, brushed-up eyebrow. Nicknamed the â€œfeathered brow,â€ her in-salon bootcamp takes thin arches (often belonging to the rich and famous) to their full potential thanks to a prescriptive protocol that includes tinting, shaping, and stylingâ€”all of which come only after her required grow-out period.

â€œThe best way to take your brows into your own hands is to first let them grow completely untouched for six to eight weeks,â€ the in-demand expert says, noting that only after this can the real work begin. â€œThis means absolutely no tweezing, threading, or trimming of any kind.â€

While this first step is undoubtedly daunting, thereâ€™s a method to her madness: Removing even a few stray hairs disturbs the hair growth cycle, so taking a hands-off approach allows dormant follicles to produce hairs you never knew you had. With social distancing mandates still in effect across many parts of the country, thereâ€™s never been a better time to take on the challenge. In fact, you may have already done this without even realizing it, which is why we tapped Streicher for a pro guide to not only growing out your brows, but grooming them with restraint once theyâ€™ve filled in. For this monthâ€™s The Consult, Streicher is taking us through a protocol for better brows.

settings.heading: STEP 1: PROMOTE GROWTH & GATHER SUPPLIES
settings.description:
Streicherâ€™s mandatory grow-in period wonâ€™t be easy, but itâ€™ll be worth it. She recommends clients apply Grande Brow Growth Serum for the best results. â€œUse it on clean, dry skin throughout the brow by using one dip per eyebrow, morning and night,â€ she says. â€œLet it soak in for two minutes before using other products.â€

Use this time to order your supplies: small, sharp scissors; professional tweezers; and a spooly brush. Pick up Streicherâ€™s Essentials Eyebrow Grooming Kitâ€”the same exact tools sheâ€™s been using for over 20 years to create â€˜feathered browsâ€™ all over the worldâ€”to make things easier. Bonus: â€œYour kit includes access to exclusive tutorials needed to create your perfect Feathered Brow, wherever you are,â€ she says.

settings.quotes: "IT'S NOT ABOUT THE HAIR YOU TAKE, BUT THE HAIR YOU LEAVE BEHIND"

settings.heading: STEP 2: TRIM & TWEEZE
settings.description:
â€œProceed with caution,â€ Streicher says. â€œAlways remember, itâ€™s not about the hair you take, but the hair you leave behind.â€ She notes that over-trimming can be just as detrimental as over-tweezing, so go slow and be conservative on both accountsâ€”it takes weeks to grow in precious hairs and only seconds to remove them.

â€œUsing the eyebrow spoolie brush and scissors, brush hair up and trim only the longer hair that protrudes past the brow line,â€ she says. â€œCut the hair where it starts to bend or curl. Trim hairs one at a time, staggering the lengths for a more natural look. Do not cut the hairs straight across or all at once.â€ Once the length of your hairs is adjusted, create a â€œbuffer zoneâ€ for tweezing with a brow pencil. â€œSimply draw a line around your entire brow,â€ she says, noting that this â€˜no-tweeze zoneâ€™ should be about the size of the tip of a cotton swab, or approximately half a centimeter. â€œTweeze only the hairs that fall outside of this!â€

For those who need additional guidance, consider Streicherâ€™s virtual appointment offerings. â€œWith these appointments you will receive detailed eyebrow tweezing and trimming instructions, custom guided grooming tips, and instructions on how to properly fill in your eyebrows,â€ she says.

settings.heading: STEP 3: STYLE
settings.description:
The brushed-up brow aesthetic is not only popular among Streciherâ€™s clientsâ€”like Mandy Moore, Adele, and Sarah Paulsonâ€”itâ€™s universally flattering and can be accomplished with just a tinted brow gel. (Professional tinting is best left to the pros for safety reasons, she says.) â€œThink of this as mascara for the brows!â€ Streicher says. â€œWhen you add volume and richness to the lighter hairs that grow around and between the thicker brow hairs, it creates the look of a fuller, more natural brow.â€

We're partial to the Rose Inc Brow Enriched Tinted Shaping Gel, which contains squalane and vitamins E and B5 to condition the brows while holding them in place. Gently work the product into the brows by brushing them backwards, against the direction of the hair growth, which adds color and volume. â€œThis picks up the hairs and wraps the gel fibers around the follicles, fluffing them up,â€ Streicher says, adding that the Hourglass Arch Brow Volumizing Gel is another trusted option. Then, before the color sets, brush them up and out before allowing them to set for a few seconds. Et VoilÃ : Your best brows.

This story was originally published on July 1, 2020.
Photographed by Jenna Jones.

Learn More: Watch Rosieâ€™s application technique in this five-minute makeup look.
